annotation.TEXT: Aside from the boss, there's not much to really say about Bomb Man's stage. It's a pretty straight-forward level to begin with, along with having all of the usual stuff seen in previous stages: Moving platforms, out of place grinders, and annoying jumps with disappearing blocks thrown in.

One other thing that gets to be a problem in this stage is certain enemy placement. For the most part, hazards are set-up in a way where the Guts Dozer will run down everything in its path. Occasionally there are a few sections like this one that make you stop and take out enemies and the structure they're standing on. I don't have a problem with the idea of having obstacles you need to watch out for (since letting the Guts Dozer do all the work here would be boring), but then come the enemies that spawn above you...

Almost the entire level involves riding atop the base of the Guts Dozer. There are two buttons here as well: The front one fires the cannon (which has a cool-down effect indicated by the bar bellow it), and the back one raises a shield that deflects most forms of projectiles. Both of these switches are necessary to use through-out the stage (especially the shield, if mainly to make things far more manageable against certain enemies).

Transition effect up ahead, obviously to skip the failed attempt at the boss. The Boobeam Traps are still annoying, but for different reasons. They spawn individually in set phases this time around, along with walls being dropped down from above to act as obstacles. The walls themselves take more hits than the usual ones, and they tend to spawn in larger quantities as the fight goes on (it's highly possible for another to spawn in a position where you just got rid of one, making it even more tedious just to get a hit on the boss).

As shown in Crash Man's stage, Guts Man is extremely iffy when it comes to enemies above him. For the most part, you can generally stand under these enemies and rain down rocks to get rid of them. That tends to work fine if it's a bunch of Tellies, but when it's a bunch of Metools or Bonnie's less jumpscare-happy cousin here (an enemy that can actively fire back at your position), it starts to get more hectic than necessary.

These "Air Tikkis" are easily the biggest offender when it comes to hazards in this stage. The resulting debris from your rocks actually won't hurt anything if you hit them first with it (or at least, the drills on the top, as seen here). They also get abused later on as an obstacle above you, preventing you from summoning rocks to deal with enemies.

Of all the fortress stages in this game, Guts Man's is probably the most unique of the bunch (along with being a good candidate for the longest stage in the game). Rather than going through this level by normal means, you get to do something a bit different...

Honestly, this is actually a pretty neat idea, and it makes for a somewhat fun level at first (barring Guts Man's mobility issues). With that being said however, this stage has its fair share of problems. First off, this level is quite long, and there's virtually no checkpoints either (although there is one at the boss door, thankfully). If you happen to die, be prepared to go through nearly all of this again.

The boss is, fittingly enough, the Guts Dozer itself. This fight mostly deals with the mechanics from the stage (since you fight it while on a Guts Dozer base, somehow). The cannon is used to take out its hand (which will constantly block out your attacks), while the shield is used to block its new laser move. It can also summon crash bombs (for whatever reason) once you get rid of its hand, but they're generally easy to avoid thanks to the way it telegraphs attacks.
